recipe.name: Giant Hash Brown
recipe.description: When you need to feed a crowd, why slave over the stove making batch after batch of hash browns when you can make one giant one?
recipeIngredient: 4 tbsp extra virgin olive oil (, separated)

recipeInstructions.text: Peel and grate the potatoes, placing the grated potato into a large bowl of water (this stops the potato from going brown while you continue grating).
recipeInstructions.name: Peel and grate the potatoes, placing the grated potato into a large bowl of water (this stops the potato from going brown while you continue grating).

recipeInstructions.text: Using a large colander, rinse the potato until the water comes clear (to remove the starch which keeps the potato from going brown as well as making it crispy).
recipeInstructions.name: Using a large colander, rinse the potato until the water comes clear (to remove the starch which keeps the potato from going brown as well as making it crispy).

recipeInstructions.text: Working a handful at a time, squeeze out the excess water and place into the bowl.
recipeInstructions.name: Working a handful at a time, squeeze out the excess water and place into the bowl.

recipeInstructions.text: Mix in 1 tbsp of olive oil, salt and pepper.
recipeInstructions.name: Mix in 1 tbsp of olive oil, salt and pepper.

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a 22cm/9 inch non stick pan over medium high heat.
recipeInstructions.name: Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a 22cm/9 inch non stick pan over medium high heat.

recipeInstructions.text: Place shredded potato mixture in pan, spread out and lightly pat down with a spatula. It should be about 1.5cm/0.6" thick.
recipeInstructions.name: Place shredded potato mixture in pan, spread out and lightly pat down with a spatula. It should be about 1.5cm/0.6" thick.

recipeInstructions.text: Cook for 5 to 8 minutes until golden brown and crispy. Use a spatula to lift a corner to check for doneness.
recipeInstructions.name: Cook for 5 to 8 minutes until golden brown and crispy. Use a spatula to lift a corner to check for doneness.

recipeInstructions.text: Get a large plate and slide the hash brown onto it.
recipeInstructions.name: Get a large plate and slide the hash brown onto it.

recipeInstructions.text: Place the pan on top of the plate, then quickly flip upside down. Use a tea towel if you need so you can hold onto the fry pan when flipping. Don't worry if it breaks when you flip it, it's salvageable!
recipeInstructions.name: Place the pan on top of the plate, then quickly flip upside down. Use a tea towel if you need so you can hold onto the fry pan when flipping. Don't worry if it breaks when you flip it, it's salvageable!

recipeInstructions.text: Drizzle the remaining 1 tbsp of oil around the edges of the fry pan. If your hash brown broke when you flipped it, use a spatula to lightly pat it back into shape.
recipeInstructions.name: Drizzle the remaining 1 tbsp of oil around the edges of the fry pan. If your hash brown broke when you flipped it, use a spatula to lightly pat it back into shape.

recipeInstructions.text: Cook until golden brown and crispy, about 4 to 6 minutes. Use a spatula to lift up to check.
recipeInstructions.name: Cook until golden brown and crispy, about 4 to 6 minutes. Use a spatula to lift up to check.

recipeInstructions.text: Slide out of the plan onto a serving plate. Season with additional salt if required. To serve, garnish with chopped parsley (optional) and cut into wedges.

review.reviewBody: This recipe works every time, as hash browns can be a bit bland I always add salt and pepper to the oil, and it really makes a difference.
My mum used to make these when we were kids (decades ago ðŸ˜€) and we called them Mock Fish, delicious!
As a complete novice I live your recipes. Put some bacon in this giant one to get the best of both worlds. Made it a little thick so cooking a little longer. Can't wait to get stuck in!

It took me a couple of attempts to get this perfect but my third go came out perfectly. I do find that cooking it for longer over a lower heat (15 min a side, medium heat) makes for a beautifully golden crust and I also prefer to cook it in butter, just browned which also contributes to the delicious flavour. I like to add some very finely diced garlic and chopped rosemary and parsley (only because that's what I have in the garden currently) to the grated potatoes... I rinse and wring mine out in a sieve lined with chux dishcloths because I'm lazy and it's way easier... and I have found this to be the ABSOLUTELY PERFECT base for Eggs Florentine. Like, I made this for brunch last weekend and got marriage proposals even though my husband was right there (he may have been slightly smug about the whole thing, until it was time to clear the table at least, ha ha!)

The best advice I can offer other readers is to make sure you have a plate big enough to easily invert your frying pan or skillet onto easily!!! And as much as I want to try this in my Lodge cast iron, I don't think I have the strength and coordination to juggle that sucker without risking it all.

A winner for me, for sure!
